Prepay required HERE 


 Men ages: 42-57 
Wom ages: 39-53 


Cost: $35.75 - $40.75 

Part 1- Informal mingle to meet others attending and make some new friends as our host introduces you to others during this group aspect of the event . 

Part 2- Up to 15 connections in one night, each lasting 4-6 minutes long.  After each round, you will circle yes or no on your scorecard as to whether or not you would be interested in corresponding with that person further.

Part 3- Everyone is welcomed to stay and mingle get to know each other more.  Besides meeting potential people for romance potential, many attendees have made some terrific new friends and business potentials. 

At the end of the evening you will turn in your scorecard for us to tally.  The next morning you will receive an email letting you know who you matched with.  The email will provide you with the person's first name and email address and they will get your first name and email address.  We even let you know the one way matches (they picked you, but you didn't pick them), just in case you change your mind

Prepay required HERE

Salsa Dancing in Times Square is Back!
LA FAMA (151 W 46th St, 11th Floor) is a Latin Party that specializes in playing and dancing to Salsa Music. The event takes place where the bright lights are. That's right, Times Square. We have a nice floor, great ventilation, fun willing dancers, and your total expense for a Friday Night is 12.00

You do not know how to Dance Salsa? No problem. We offer a Free Salsa class at 9:30pm every Friday. So come alone or bring your friends,. Either way, you are guaranteed to learn and have a blast.
You know what else is back? The music. LA FAMA is bringing the music back to the forefront. That's Right, DJ Mustachio will be in th building playing foot stomping flavorful Salsa songs to get those hips moving and grooving.

results.description:
Due to the heavy rains, this event has been cancelled by Time's Up. However, thank you for your interest and I will schedule another bike event in the near future! 

___________________________________________________________________ 

Let's join Time's Up, NYC's Direct Action Environmental Organization, for their monthly Moonlight Ride in Central Park.  From their website: 

"This is a fun, relaxing auto-free ride through Central Park. Enjoy the tranquility of the park & its beautiful ponds & waterways: a nature lover's dream. Totally safe. Bike guides front & rear."

We will meet as our meetup at 9:45pm at 240 Central Park South (aka 240 W59th Street), outside the FedEx building.  From there at 9:55pm, we will join the Time's Up organization at Columbus Circle.  


The ride is at a leisurely pace.  You should of course bring a bicycle (any type of bicycle will work, other than a moped or motorbike) and be ready to go.  A helmet is recommended.  Lights are not required, (although if you have them you should bring them).  The ride is expected to end by 12 midnight, at Columbus Circle, and total distance is approximately 10 miles.  

See you there!

Edward
results.how_to_find_us: Cancelled due to rain - 240 Central Park South (aka 240 W59th Street), outside the FedEx building
results.name: Cancelled due to heavy rains - Moonlight Bike Ride - Central Park

results.description:
It's time to head to the Catskills to hike one of the best known,


most grueling trails on the east coast!

We will go west to east this time! 

Go at your pace. Suggest you find "hiking buddies" to hike with.

Everyone goes on the waitlist. I will take responsible hikers who have hiked with me previously. Responsible means you know what to do to get yourself out of a "tough" situation and are willing to help others in case the need arises.

http://www.backpacker.com/january-2011-readers-choice-northeast-new_york-devils_path/destinations/15048

Five peaks over 3500' .. 24 miles .. 9000' of vertical gain!

5am: Meeting at car spot location (Prediger Road) Everyone MUST meet here to spot cars. We will then drive to the starting point.

Everyone will hike at their own pace, the first 4 licensed drivers to complete the hike will collect the cars from the starting point. We will hide the keys at the trailhead. If you don't leave your keys you are responsible for getting your own car.

Expect to be hiking for 10-14 hours!

Since we will all be hiking at a different pace, try to find someone in the group who hikes at your pace -

FOLKS SHOULD HAVE SOME LONG DISTANCE (20 miles or more) HIKE EXPERIENCE BEFORE DOING THIS HIKE.. THERE WILL BE NO SWEEP!

+++

NOTE: You are responsible for bringing appropriate gear, supplies, clothing, first aid, and lights. You should review topographic maps and trail features carefully; understanding topography of any hike is key to your knowing where you are, where you're going, and how to get back. See suggestions for GEAR on the "About" page for additional gear ideas. You agree when you sign up for this group or any of the events that you have read and understand the below. If you join us for a hike (or any other event), please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness and well-being and will hold no one else liable in case of injury or mishap. You agree not to hold the Organizer, Assistant Organizers, or any other members responsible for any injuries, mishaps, or any other situation that may happen at a planned event. You are responsible to research the event, know the area, and bring the proper gear. Your attendance on a hike signifies that you have read and accept the terms of this liability waiver. Full waiver can be found on the ABOUT page.
results.name: Infamous DEVIL'S PATH TRAVERSE!  Expert hikers only

results.description:
On the day of the Kentucky Derby you will have your shot at completing the HVH triple crown. This will be the grand finale as Stephen Miller takes HVH'ers on an EPIC 50+ Mile journey from the GWB to the Bear Mountain Bridge!! 

May 7, 2016 URBAN HIKING SERIES -Triple Crown Part 3- 

GW Bridge to Bear Mountain Bridge ~50 miles 

 This hike is Part 3 of the three part URBAN HIKING SERIES Triple Crown. You can participate in as many as you like. For those hardy souls who finish all three, there will be a special reward. 

 Meet time: Sunrise 5:45 A.M. at 179th Street and Fort Washington Ave. 

 On the day of the Kentucky Derby- the fastest two minutes in sports- we will do the fastest 50 miles in HVH for 2016. Thoroughbreds only. This trek will start on the Manhattan side of the George Washington Bridge and head up the Hudson River Greenway to the northern tip of the island before heading over the Henry Hudson Bridge into The Bronx. We will carry on through some beautiful sections of Fieldston and Riverdale before heading over to Broadway and making our way into Yonkers in southern Westchester County. 

At that point, we will connect with the Old Croton Aqueduct Trail and head up to its northern terminus at the New Croton Dam in Northern Westchester. Fromm that point we will find our way further up Northern Westchester until we reach our ultimate destination, the east side of the Bear Mountain Bridge.I will fill in specific details of the last portion of the route as we get closer to the date but I anticipate it covering between 48-50 miles and lasting about 15 hours-16 hours which will take us to about 9 or 10 o'clock. Sunset is scheduled for ~7:45 P.M. so the last miles will be in the dark.There will be numerous bailouts along the way as the route tracks Metro North once we reach Westchester County. Come with your legs, heart, and mental commitment you will be rewarded with a very fulfilling experience and the energy from the group will enable you to cover distances you didn't think were possible.look forward to seeing you all. CARPE DIEM!!!


FROM HERE:

TO HERE:

results.name: 2016 URBAN HIKING SERIES Triple Crown Part 3- GW Bridge to BEAR MOUNTAIN BRIDGE

REGISTRATION FOR THE GREAT SAUNTER IS NOW OPEN AT SHOREWALKERS.ORG!


Please do RSVP for The Great Saunter here on Meetup and share questions, answers, tips, and plans for your walk with your fellow walkers but please, please, please understand that in order to participate you must register for The Great Saunter at shorewalkers.org!  

Here is the link to all the Great Saunter information: The Great Saunter

If you registered online before April 14 material will be mailed out on April 18th.


If you register after April 14, bring your registration receipt with you (print, phone, tablet) on May 7th to pick up your material.  


You can register with cash or check the day of the Great Saunter, but day-of registration will not include Shorewalkers membership. 

If you have any questions about your Shorewalkers membership, send an email to [masked]


If you have questions about Great Saunter registration, send an email to [masked].

results.description:
Kalalau Trail, Hawaii


http://www.kauaiexplorer.com/hiking_kauai/kalalau_hike.php


Информации очень много и на интернете и на ютубе.

Планируется в первой половине мая 2016 года.

Климат - райский.

Одежда - можно идти вообще голым.

11 миль в один конец - можно сделать за один день.

В конечной точке (пляж и тёплое море) - зависание на 2 или 3 дня, живём как бомжи. 

Помимо палаточного путешествия, на обратном пути можно снять жильё на пару дней и попутешествовать в компании на минивене по острову. Для этого двух дней будет достаточно.

Вся поездка - 9 дней.

Желающие, должны иметь backpacking experience и необходимое снаряжение - ботинки, рюкзаки, мешки, палатки и т. п.

Место встречи - остров Kauai, Hawaii.

results.description:
Lets do a little urban hiking by walking  around the entire  island of Manhattan. At 3 miles an hour this walk will take at least 10 hours but the good thing is you can bail anytime you wish. I've done this walk for the last four years and even though there is no elevation gain its still a challenge .

Summary of walk:

The Great Saunter is a 32‐mile walk around Manhattan’s rim. The pace is steady, but not fast. Most of the route is fairly flat. We keep to the waterside as much as possible. We’ll go rain or shine and many of us will make it round, regardless of the weather. We walk through more than twenty parks and promenades and touch dozens of communities and cultures. Along the way are many points from which you can easily join the group or drop off and catch public transportation. 

You can do part of the walk or half or all it's up to you.Please bring your friends and family out for a great day of exercise ,sighting seeing and enjoying that spring feeling.

Route InformationInteractive Map: 

The Great Saunter

Route Information--route instructions, bathrooms, markets: 

About the Route


If you want a certificate of your accomplishment Please read below.

THE GREAT SAUNTER IS FREE WITH PAID MEMBERSHIP TO SHOREWALKERS.  PAID MEMBERS MUST STILL REGISTER AT SHOREWALKERS.ORG IN ORDER TO PARTICIPATE. 

INDIVIDUAL MEMBERSHIP IS $20 PER YEAR AND INCLUDES ONE FREE REGISTRANT IN THE GREAT SAUNTER, FAMILY MEMBERSHIP IS $20 PER YEAR AND AN ADDITIONAL $10 PER FAMILY MEMBER, EACH PAID MEMBERS GETS FREE REGISTRATION IN THE GREAT SAUNTER.

ALL PARTICIPANTS MUST REGISTER FOR THE GREAT SAUNTER IN ORDER TO RECEIVE RACE NUMBERS AND ROUTE MAP IN THE MAIL. PLEASE REGISTER IN ADVANCE AND MAKE THE GREAT SAUNTER EASIER AND MORE ENJOYABLE FOR YOURSELF AND OUR WONDERFUL VOLUNTEERS.

If you sign up with a "family member" it brings down the cost for everyone.

If you plan on doing this event a few things to consider beforehand:

Make sure you have comfortable broken in shoes

Take a least 3 pairs of socks with you.

Pick up some blister remedies 

Take as little as possible with you. Walk passes through inwood/washington hts so you  can pickup food and water there.

Have a metro card on hand.

Ask me questions now don't wait until the event.

Tom G

[masked]

results.name: The Great Saunter 32 mile walk around Manhattan

Game style and Rules:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

The van has 13 available seats and seats cost $22 per person + $1 paypal fee.

The seats are first come, first serve. To claim a seat, RSVP to this event and make your payment.  If you MUST pay in cash, then contact me immediately at [masked] to make arrangements.

Please read ALL OF THE DETAILS BELOW before you RSVP and pay for your van seat.  They will detail the time we will leave the city, where to meet and what time we will leave CT.

IMPORTANT DETAILS BELOW:

On Saturday morning, please meet us at 8:00 AM in front of the Starbucks at:

1841 Broadway # 2, New York, NY

This is the corner of 60th Street and Broadway. Right off Columbus circle and across the street from the Jazz Center.

• Satellite View:
https://goo.gl/maps/YwFNq

Street View:
https://goo.gl/maps/RqJHS

The 1,A,B,C,and D trains all stop at Columbus Circle.

WE WILL BE HEADING OUT AT 8:15 AM. We apologize, but in order for things to run smoothly, if you are not there by 8:15 AM we will be heading to CT without you.

We expect to arrive at the castle around 10:30 am.

We don't have a firm leaving time yet. We need to check what time the park closes. Also last year many of the cosplayers went to the local IKEA for dinner (only place that could hold so many of us ;). If EVERYONE in the van wants to go eat, then we will as well.


Some additional details:

- The van has a 13 person capacity, so first come, first serve. You need to RSVP and pay the fee via the Meetup.com payment system.

- Our van will leave Columbus Circle the day of the event at 8:15 am SHARP. We cannot wait even if you TXT me, or call me, or send a Patronus.


- I will not be able to provide refunds after April 15th. That is the cut off if you find out you no longer want to be on the van.

- I will activate the Meetup.com waiting list for this event, so if anyone drops out, the next person in the list will have the ability to take that seat and pay the fee. If this is before April 15th, the person who dropped will get a refund.

---

As always if you have any questions you can contact me at [masked]

Fun Play 
No Sliding 
Goals after half point only. 
Kick-ins.. no throw ins. 
Corner kicks. 
Kick-off at midpoint after each goal.

To promote generosity, honor and respect PS2G plays clean soccer! This means no cursing, insulting, complaining, arguing or fighting! We welcome you if this is your usual style or if you want to change your attitude to fit our culture.

The proceeds go to our charity network: http://ps2g.org/charities

PS2G enables soccer players to organize fundraising pickup games that support our charity network ultimately promoting the safe play of soccer for disadvantaged children.

results.description:
Join us at 8am for a run to Hoboken Pier A and back.
http://www.mapmyrun.com/routes/view/121375029

Yes, there is a waterfront route to Hoboken. Enjoy the fun of cruising around Hoboken Pier A; around the new park and children playground at Newport where you will feel if you are at the beach. Get inspired by the man made majestic views of Manhattan!

The mapped distance is approx. 5.88 miles. You may run less or more in that time. We turn back after running 30 min to be back at 9 am. Hyatt pier is .31 miles so a double loop gets some runners 6.5 miles on this run.

9 am we run to Liberty State Park, a favorite place to run for most of us. Run on!

results.description: Up the Timp Thorne trail , to Timp Thorne,  reverse direction to connect to the RD  followed back to cars. Includs peak bagging Bald Mt.   Expect  1600’ elevation gain : my slow pace:  a  little more than my normal mileage  8 miles: but will include the normal  stops to hydrate, eat, enjoy the views (14).  No early out  Both trails are orphans seeking a parental mountaineer landscaper: aka trail maintainer under the asepsis of the AMC, TC, and Harriman State Park.  To become a maintainer of one of these trails, membership in the AMC is required. What you walk,  half could become yours to manicure,  mark / hammer up tags,  and save from water erosion.  Building water bars is apart of the duties.  Bring your favorite insect  repellent, a quart and half of liquids, gear for whatever 30 % chance of precipitation means after you check the local radar.  Transportation : take the 7:43 Metro North  Hudson Line train  from Grand Central Station  arriving in  Tarrytown  station  at 8:22.  Drivers meet to shuttle from there to 9W parking lot,  next to the “jungle”.  An introduction to a vegetative mass  through which we gays and gals must pass, and is  the responsbility whomever will be its maintainer  keeping it open, clear, and free of yukee spider webs. I can offer three rides back to the City  for return  Leader Bill Hladky 914. 874. 4640. [masked]

results.description:
Weather permitting, come join us for outdoor tennis at Washington Park in Union City, which is off of the 9th Street light rail station. Bring your sweats, your racquet, plenty of water and balls and we'll see you there! As this event is not designed to match up folks, courts are assigned on first-come first-served basis. So get in early and grab a court.


Make sure you only use 3-4 of the same numbered balls. Public courts do not allow use of more than 6 balls per court.

Also please try to use the same age balls as it will help you improve your game.

You can find each other in the waiting area and/or looking on the courts. It would help if you make a mental note of the profile picture of those attending.

Although we won't enforce attendance, it would be polite to attend if you commit because others are looking to find others to hit with.

Cross your fingers that it won't rain as inclement weather cancels the event.

If you have any questions, feel free to email the organizer.

1 game (7 v 7) : Two halves of 30 minutes each with a break in between

-Please bring a fun and chill attitude. Absolutely no rough playing, slide-tackling or berating others; You’ll be asked to leave.

-Turf, AG cleats, or sneakers - no wet ground monster spikes.

-$4.00 goes for maintaining the website, equipment, and organization.

Rules:

This is a chill game so please bring a chill attitude; no meatheads or a$$holes. Organizers have the final say (i.e. if a ball is out of bounds we call it).
It’s a small pitch so no corners kicks; just throwins.

Directions:

How to get to Brooklyn Bridge Park PIER 2 Sports Field:

To get past the BQE, you must enter Brooklyn Bridge Park on foot either fromm the south (at Joralemon St. & Furman St.) or the north (at Old Fulton St. & Furman St.) Pier 2 is roughly halfway between these two entrances. We play on the artificial grass field at the far end of the pier, behind the basketball courts & roller rink.

Google these coordinates:[masked], [masked]

Brooklyn Bridge Park is accessible by several subway lines (A/C, 2/3, 4/5, F, R) and bus routes (B25, B63)

Cancellation: We'll play rain or shine. We'll only cancel if there are fewer than 10 people going, or if there's lightning in the area.

Late cancellations and no-shows will get you removed from future events.

results.description:
REGISTER HERE

Truth: A Day-Long Channeled Workshop in NYC

“Authentic, straightforward truth straight from the source field.”
– Deepak Chopra on the work of Paul Selig

Award-winning author and channel Paul Selig will lead an all-new, intensive, channeled, day-long workshop where you will work directly with his Guides and their practical program for achieving personal growth and overcoming the obstacles that are hindering you on the way. Recent workshop have been taking these teachings to new heights and participants have been reporting some of the strongest shifts taking place in these sessions. Through lectures, attunements, Q&A and energy work, Paul and his Guides will lead you on an unprecedented journey of self-development to achieve new levels of alignment, healing and life purpose.

The workshop will take place in the comfortable, quiet and intimate Garamond Room at the Ink48 Hotel. This is a 10-minute walk from the subway stations at Times Square and Port Authority Bus Terminal and a 10-minute cab ride from Penn Station and Grand Central Station.

Advance Registration is available for $125 until April 23rd. Thereafter, General Registration is $150.

In this workshop, you will:

* Receive individual instruction and teaching from Paul’s Guides
* Experience the new teachings coming through for Paul’s forthcoming book, The Book of Truth
* Become attuned to a higher frequency in a way that you can trust and feel
* Learn to send and receive healing energies
* Develop your own abilities as an empath
* Free yourself from patterns of limitation and fear
* Gain tools to transform your life and awaken to your own divine nature

From recent workshop attendees:

“Paul’s workshop really was life-altering in a wonderful way. The presence he channels is clearly other, but the listener detects a profound understanding of human nature, a delightful sense of humor, and a very wise and honest perspective on the flawed world we have created.”
– Ellen Heath

“As A Course in Miracles student for many years, I had always wondered what it would have been like to bear witness to Helen Shucman’s channeling of that masterpiece, in the late 1960’s. Forty years later, we can do just that. Even more miraculous, we are now called to bear witness to the Divine within. We are called, like Paul, to do the work of Awakening. It is time to join millions around the world who are rising, ever rising in frequency, despite the headlines. It is time to get off the spiritual buffet line and put the books down for a bit. It is time to experience being IN Love. It is work, this workshop. And it is glorious.”
– John Crotty 

ABOUT PAUL SELIG

Paul Selig is a writer, empath and conscious channel. He received his Master’s Degree from Yale and served on the faculty of NYU for over 25 years. A spiritual experience in 1987 left him clairvoyant. His breakthrough works of channeled literature, I Am the Word, The Book of Love and Creation, The Book of Knowing and Worth and The Book of Mastery have quickly become the most important and celebrated expression of channeling since A Course in Miracles rose to prominence in the 1970s. Paul’s workshops have won a growing following around the world for their depth, intimacy, and psychological insight.

results.description:
The core of the oven is built, but we're not done yet! Learn the basics of masonry and lay bricks to build the outer facing of the oven.

Join the team to lay the beautiful red brick facing that will make this oven a twin to the Old Stone House and protect it for generations to come.  We'll also be beautifying the oven area.

This final phase of oven construction will extend over several weekends throughout the month of May. Feel free to join all day long or for just a couple of hours. No prior bricklaying experience is required!

When the oven is finished, weIf you come participate in one or more of these building days, we'll put your name on the oven on a brass dedEveryone who participates will be named on the dedication plaque as a "Builder of the Oven"!

Work gloves, tools, and refreshing drinks will be provided!

(Boots or heavy shoes are recommended.)
results.name: Community Bricklaying Day: Oven and Fireplace Facing

results.description:
Do you know all you need to know to safely ride a bike with traffic? The Smart Cycling program gives you the tips, tools, and techniques to confidently ride your bike in all conditions. This class is sponsored by Westchester Cycle Club and open to the public. It is appropriate for those who are new to riding on the roads and those who have been riding their bike a long time--anyone who wants to feel more confident about riding safely on the roads. We will discuss riding safely in traffic, including choosing the correct lane, scanning for nearby cars, signaling, changing lanes, navigating traffic lights, and turning against traffic. We will also reinforce your confidence to choose an appropriate bike and visible clothing, navigate road hazards and changing weather, ride in a group, and make emergency maneuvers when needed. The class includes classroom and on-road components. You must attend both days (Saturday and Sunday). Please don't reserve a spot unless you are sure that you can attend both sessions. Plan to bring your bike and helmet for on-road riding and parking lot drills. Plan to bring lunch on Saturday. Class size is limited to 15.

The class will be taught by Ellen Katz and Lisa Baker, who are both League Cycling Instructors, certified by the League of American Bicyclists to teach this curriculum. Ellen is current Safety & Education chair for Westchester Cycle Club, and Lisa is immediate past Safety & Education chair. Learn more about the LAB Smart Cycling curriculum at http://bikeleague.org/ridesmart

When: Saturday May 7, 9:00 AM - 3:00 PM and Sunday, May 8, 9:00 AM to 1:00 PM
Where: White Plains YMCA, 250 Mamaroneck Ave, White Plains, NY 10605
Cost: $20 (covers cost of materials)
How to sign up: Email Lisa Baker at [masked] to secure your spot
Deadline to sign up: May 1, 2016
results.name: Smart Cycling (Instructional Class)

results.description:
We'll meet in front of the Red Barn Bakery for a run on the Old Croton Aqueduct. Afterward, whoever is interested can head to the Red Barn Bakery for breakfast. This is a good run for new runners because it is out and back - no set distance to cover but you will need to wear a watch. Feel free to turnaround at any point or walk/run at your own pace. 

Details about the Saturday run

Route: We’ll meet in front of the Red Barn Bakery (4 S. Astor St.) in Irvington and jog VERY casually together to the Old Croton Aqueduct trail. (If you are unfamiliar with the area and would prefer to walk rather than run to the trail, click here to see the trail on a map.) From there we’ll head south toward Dobbs Ferry. There is no set distance. Everyone will walk or run at their own pace for 25 minutes, and then turn around and come back. Please wear a watch so that you know when to turn around.

Water/Bag Storage: There are very few water fountains along the route, so bring a water bottle if you need one while running. I’ll bring water and cups for after the run. There’s no bag storage, so leave belongings at home or in your car.

Location: In front of Red Barn Bakery (4 S. Astor St, Irvington, NY 10533). Free parking is available on weekends in the MetroNorth lot next door.

</a>  <a href="https://www.facebook.com/groups/1452433901730637/">Join our Facebook group to post pictures or message other members.

General advice & guidelines for our regular meetup runs:

• RSVP if you are going. If your plans change, simply change your RSVP.

• There is no bag storage, so please bring only what you plan to run with.

• All regular runs are rain or shine, unless the weather is actually dangerous.

• If you arrive late, can’t find the start location, miss us for any reason, run anyway!

Feel free to contact me either via my meetup account or at [masked] if you have any questions.

Oh yeah, AND FREE COMICS!!!

Get here early because the festivities start early!

results.description:
It is the "Happiest 5k on the planet!" The Color Run at CitiField on May 7th is the place to be that weekend. Knowing that most of us are multitasks, we are killing two birds with one stone here - getting our running game up while we socialize (and get sprayed with colored powder). 

This is event will be the best with the most - hoping with can get a big group out there. If you are worried you are not up for the run, come anyway. This event is a party 1st and a run 2nd. It will be great to have all our BPOLA'ers out there in force. Also, make sure to dress in your Sunday whites!

Link for tickets and more information: http://thecolorrun.com/locations/queens-ny/

Prices go up by $5 on April 6th!


Thanks to Eva D. for suggesting the event!

Read the Event Guide to be informed about clear bags and NYPD security checks, and fanny packs...if you are fashionably willing :( 

Also check out the  MTA trip planner for your urban subway excursion on Saturday.

There will be two meeting locations:

First Meetup Location: under parking Lot F sign (Near Check-In Tables)

Time: 8am - 9:15 am (The start window closes promptly at 10 am)  We can start walking over to the start window at 9:15 am since they will be starting in waves of people.

If we miss you at the beginning of the race, then we will have a second meeting location at 10:30 am, which I will announce closer  to the time. It probably will be somewhere in the party area.

Remember walkers are welcome. There will be a separate path for runners and walkers alike at the Color Run.

Second Meetup Location:   Under the parking lot F sign, which is near the check in tables.

Time: 10:30 am

My number is[masked]-7962. See you tomorrow

results.description:
Just putting this on the calendar in a recurring fashion to allow for people to plan ahead and see if we can make more people intersect.

These will be mostly (unless highlighted) in Watching Reservation, but may occasionally detour to Loantaka, Washington Park, South Mountain and so one. 

In every case, the idea will be to be at that location at 9:30, and to be done at the very last at 10:30. Carpooling may be organized in some cases (via the FB group for efficiency). The trail will be decided when we leave. Whatever strikes our fancy, take a look at past meetups to get a sense. No runner left behind as I will be at back panting heavily anyway. 

If you're wondering wether you're up for a 1 hour run - let us know and we can shorten it or make sure we set our pace adequately. The idea is to enjoy ourselves and nature, not to set any speed records.

Note that this is a member-run meetup: no one is responsible for you but you. Your event host is not responsible for you or any injuries that could happen as you willingly run across rough terrain with roots, rocks, gullies, etc. Don't expect anyone to have first aid knowledge, supplies, or water for you. Just a bunch of like-minded people enjoying the trails together! For more details see section 6.2 of http://www.meetup.com/terms/

results.description:
THIS EVENT WILL SELL OUT!   REGISTER ASAP


I have been attending One Day University every year for several years now and I always come away raving about the lectures because the Professors who teach here are stars!


Every school has one or maybe two professors that are wildly popular. These are the ones for whom students will sometimes sleep outdoors the night before registration in order to get into their classes! 

Well, those are the professors who teach at One Day U! Amazing professors from Harvard, Yale, Stanford, Amherst, Princeton, Georgetown, Brown and many many more. 

The pace of the day is brisk and stimulating, the professors eager and enthusiastic, the classroom electric with the excitement of learning! But unlike "regular" college, at One Day University there are no grades. No tests. No homework.


Here's the list of this day's lectures:

FULL SCHEDULE:  May 7th, New York City  

9:30 AM - 10:40 AM

Reinventing English: The Future of Reading, Writing and Thinking

Seth Lerer  /  University of California at San Diego 

Should English be an official language; what standards do we use in public discourse; what happens when cultures come together and introduce new words; what role does technology have in language change? These are all questions that have been asked for a thousand years, when the Anglo-Saxons first committed "English" into writing and created poetry and prose of power and imagination.
English has always been "re-invented" by everyone who speaks and writes it. In this course, we will search for ways of anticipating future changes to the language and prepare for a world in which English will be re-invented before our eyes and ears.

10:55 AM - 12:05 PM

America's Founders: What Were They Really Like?

Joanne Freeman/  Yale University

America's founders were ambitious. They were grouchy (especially John Adams). They were scared. They were hopeful. They told jokes (sometimes dirty ones.) They fought. They schemed. They gossiped.  They occasionally killed each other (sorry, Alexander Hamilton.) They sometimes made great big crashing mistakes. And above all, they were human.  Responding to an awestruck letter written to him in his old age, John Adams replied: "Let me tell you a very great secret, as far as I am capable of comparing the merit of different periods, I have no reason to believe we were better than you."
Only by seeing the Founders as human can we appreciate the full story of the nation's founding with all of its drama, humor, and significance intact. This talk will explore what it felt like to be one of the nation's founders, standing on the national stage, bringing an experimental government to life, and wondering what would happen next.

12:05 PM - 1:25 PM
Lunch Break     Students will have 1 hour and 20 minute lunch break. You may bring your own or purchase it at a nearby restaurant.

1:25 PM - 2:35 PM

How Religion Changes Your Brain

Andrew Newberg  /  Thomas Jefferson University Medical School In this presentation, students will learn about breakthrough discoveries in religion and the brain. Not only do prayer and spiritual practice reduce stress and anxiety, but just 12 minutes of meditation per day may actually slow down the aging process. Contemplating a loving God rather than a punitive God reduces anxiety, depression, and stress, and increases feelings of security and compassion.
Fundamentalism, can be personally beneficial, but the anger and prejudice generated by extreme beliefs can permanently damage your brain. Intense prayer and meditation permanently change numerous structures and functions in the brain, altering your values and the way you perceive reality. Professor Newberg will also explain the best ways to "exercise" your brain and guide you through specific routines derived from a wide variety of Eastern and Western spiritual practices that improve personal awareness and empathy. 

2:50 PM - 4:00 PM

The Politics of Islam: The Good, The Bad, The Future 

Tarek Masoud  /  Harvard University

Professor Tarek Masoud is one of America's leading authorities on Islam, and in this presentation he will draw on a lifetime of thought and research to provide an accurate, richly nuanced, and revelatory account of the fastest growing religion in the world. We'll explore the major questions and issues that face Islam in the 21st century that will deeply affect global politics. Is Islam compatible with modern notions of democracy, rule of law, gender equality, and human rights? How representative and widespread is Islamic fundamentalism and the threat of global terrorism? Can Muslim minority communities be loyal citizens in America and Europe?
In the midst of these difficult questions Professor Masoud will turn the mirror on the US and Europe and paint a revealing portrait of how we appear to Muslims. Recent decades have brought extraordinary changes in the Muslim world, and in addressing these issues this class presents  a complex picture of Islam in all its diversity-a picture of urgent importance as we face the challenges of the coming century.

********************************************************************

REGISTRATION - The regular price for this event is $179, but there is an early-bird price available for $109. Click here to register and enter code NY109.  This is a limited time discount offer.  If this code has expired, try code LEARN for a 30% discount totaling $125 or code NY129 for $129.

This event is extremely popular, so if you're interested, register as soon as you can.


***********************************************************************


DINNER:  For those of you who may wish to have dinner following the event, I have made a reservation at Pio Pio, 702 Amsterdam Avenue at 94th Street (a few blocks away) at 5pm.  Right now that reservation is for 10 people but I may be able to up the count if there is a lot of interest.

Pio Pio is a lively restaurant that offers creative cocktails and mammoth portions of ceviches and moist Peruvian chicken at a reasonable cost. Combination platters are shareable: the Matador Combo holds tostones, sausage, a whole marinated chicken, avocado salad and fries. 

Their famous Peruvian rotisserie birds are marinated for 12 hours in a mixture of cumin, garlic, Peruvian beer, and a few other key ingredients the owners prefer to keep a trade secret.  Zagat says it’s the best chicken in New York City. 

See their menu at http://www.piopio.com/menu/104&m=10.html

*******************************************************************************

If you would like to be included for dinner please leave a note in the comments section and confirm that:

1.  You have purchased your ticket for the One Day University event.

2.  You would like to join us for dinner

NO MAYBE’S PLEASE.  ONLY RESPOND IF YOU ARE COMMITTED TO ATTENDING.  Our reservation is limited.  Do not deny someone else the opportunity to attend if you are not sure you will make it.

results.description:
Horseback Trail Riding

More than horseback tours, our trail rides follow the paths of the ancient Indians from mountainside to swiftly running streams, beside centuries old rock walls.

A love for horses and an adventuresome spirit are required for all participants.

For your safety, enjoyment and the consideration of others, please be honest about your riding ability.

All rides are guided. Children must be at least 7 years of age to ride on the trails and riders must weigh below 225 pounds including clothing and shoes.

After the riding, we can have lunch at picturesque City Island.

Kazimiroff Nature Trail - Pelham Bay Park

After lunch, we can have a walk in Kazimiroff Nature Trail - Best Walk New York 2012 according to the Village Voice, and Orchard Beach. An easy walk of about 2 miles long.

Depart Date: May 7th Saturday; arrive 15 minutes earlier.

Depart 9:30 AM from Chinatown: (1 Block from B, D Grand St Subway Station ) Northwest corner of Broome St. & Forsyth St., New York, NY 10002 (Map)

Depart 9:40 AM from Union Square: (Walgreen) Southeast corner of 4th Ave. & 14th St., New York, NY 10003 (Map)

Depart 10:00 AM from Midtown West: (Garden City Deli) Northwest corner of West 43rd St. & 9th Ave, New York, NY 10036 (Map)

Return: Expect to be back in Midtown West at 5:00 PM, Union Square at 5:25 PM and Chinatown at 5:45 PM


Requirement: Weigh below 225 pounds including clothing and shoes

Cost: Early birds $59 for first 8 spots or 10 days in advance; Regular $69 afterward. Please only RSVP here after you have purchased the ticket.

Trip includes: Round trip transportation from NYC, 1 hour of horseback riding & park walking in Kazimiroff Nature Trail. Must weight below 225 pounds.


Buy Ticket Here: http://may2016horsebackriding.eventbrite.com/ or you can Chase Quickpay me the amount indicated above to [masked] to avoid transaction fee (How to Use Chase Quickpay?) If Quickpaying, please indicate your boarding location. Your spot is not confirmed until your payment is received.

* Full refund minus $10 processing fee if cancelled 2 weeks in advance;
* Afterward, no refund for cancellation or no show; however, you can transfer your spot to other with $10 transfer fee.

results.description:
LEADER: Roy Wooters ([masked] or[masked])

RATING:  B 7.5/8 B

Please arrive 15 minutes early for introductions and to get situated. Meet at 9:30 AM at the parking on Taylor Road just west of NY State Route 32. We'll use the Sweet Clover, Jessup, Western Ridge, Ridge to Ridge, and Dark Hollow Trails. Some rock scrambles. Please register via e-mail with phone number. Heavy rain cancels. TC West Hudson Trails map 114.

Note that this hike is part of a larger group, the NJR ADK. Most hikers sign up via our printed schedule (see below) and not through Meetup, so though the number of attendees may appear small, we generally have a group of 10-20 on any given hike.


*   *   *   *   *   *

Our full hike schedule can be viewed on our website at hudsonhikers.org, and some hikes are also posted on our Facebook page.

After attending two hikes/events, please consider joining the North Jersey Ramapo Chapter of the Adirondack Mountain Club to support our outdoor recreation and conservation activities.  Membership comes with a variety of benefits including a 10% discount at Ramsey Outdoor; our annual holiday party and social; special events such as our traditional day-outing to the Mohonk Mountain House; a subscription to ADK’s bi-monthly magazine, Adirondac; and the opportunity to contribute to the preservation and extension of hiking lands and viewsheds in our region.

New hikers are strongly encouraged to select hikes appropriate to their capabilities. North Jersey Ramapo Chapter hikes are rated for pace (A, B or C), mileage, and terrain (A, B or C), with "C" designating easier hikes and "A" more challenging ones. We recommend that new hikers should first try a "C" or short "B" hike before undertaking a more difficult one; otherwise, you may not fully enjoy the hiking experience. If you have any doubts, please contact the hike leader in advance. 

Pace Ratings: 
     A = Fast - 2.5 mph or faster 
     B = Moderate - about 2 mph 
     C = Easy - 1.5 mph or less 

Distance: Noted in miles 

Terrain Ratings:
     A = Strenuous, long/steep climbs and descents, 
             possible rock scrambling
     B = Moderate climbs and descents
     C = Generally flat with little elevation change 

For example, a hike rated “B-7-A” is a moderately paced hike of approximately 7 miles with steep climbs and/or descents and possible rock scrambling. 

If you join us for a hike, please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness, including ensuring that the hike is appropriate for your level of fitness, that you wear the proper clothing, and bring the proper gear, food and water (see the ADK's recommended Hiking Essentials and guidelines, below).

Leaders have the right, responsibility and sole discretion to refuse any hiker he/she deems to be not properly attired, prepared, or otherwise fit to safely complete the hike. 

HIKERS' GUIDELINES:

  Risks:  As with all physical activities, hiking involves hazards. Persons participate at their own risk and will be asked to sign a statement acknowledging that fact before starting the hike. Prior to the hike please advise the leader of any medical condition or physical impairment that could affect you during the hike.

  Footwear and Clothing:  Wear clothing suited to the weather and carry extra garments for unexpected weather conditions. Dress in thin layers so that you can adjust the number of layers as required to maintain comfort. In winter carry a wool cap and wool or polypropylene gloves or mitts and a windproof shell. Be prepared for rain. Bring a rain jacket and rain pants, preferably of the type that permits venting body moisture. Wear comfortable, sturdy boots/shoes.  Do not wear cotton garments in winter.

  Drink and Food:  Adequate hydration is important year round. Drink frequently during the hike. Carry food to enjoy during the midday lunch stop.

  Other responsibilities:  Hikers with children under 16 and new hikers are required to contact the hike leader in advance to determine if the hike is suitable for them.  Minors under 16 are welcome on day hikes when accompanied by a parent or guardian.  No person under 18 shall participate in overnight outings unless accompanied by a parent or adult sponsor over 21.  The hike leader may refuse to allow a person to hike who is judged to be poorly equipped or unable to do the published hike.  Participants should get to the hike at least 10 minutes prior to the starting time.

  Maps:  The TC number indicates a NY-NJ Trail Conference map for the area of the hike. For example: TC-118 refers to the Southern Harriman Park map.

  Abbreviations:  NCA-No Calls After . . . , Pref.- Leader’s contact preference.

  Expense Sharing:  When car-pooling, passengers are expected to offer the driver funds sufficient to cover the cost of fuel, tolls and parking fees. A $3.00 minimum per person is recommended. Most hike trailhead meeting locations can be found on NY-NJ Trail Conference maps.

  Dog-Friendly Hikes:  Pets are not permitted on hikes unless the hike description clearly states that it is "dog friendly."  If it is, all hikers with dogs must abide by park leash regulations.

NO SHOW/LATE CANCELLATION POLICY:
Please be considerate of event hosts/organizers and others who may want to attend an event by not being a "NO SHOW" (failing to show up when you've RSVP'd "yes") or a "LATE CANCEL" (changing RSVP to a "no" within 24 hours of an event).  If you have a history of No Shows and/or Late Cancels, we may have to bump you to the waiting list for meetups with limited space, in favor of those with a positive attendance history.

results.description:
I am excited to announce that the next book we will be covering is another amazing development book called, "The Go Giver."

The Go-Giver tells the story of an ambitious young man named Joe who yearns for success. Joe is a true go-getter, though sometimes he feels as if the harder and faster he works, the further away his goals seem to be. And so one day, desperate to land a key sale at the end of a bad quarter, he seeks advice from the enigmatic Pindar, a legendary consultant referred to by his many devotees simply as the Chairman.

Over the next week, Pindar introduces Joe to a series of “go-givers:” a restaurateur, a CEO, a financial adviser, a real estate broker, and the “Connector,” who brought them all together. Pindar’s friends share with Joe the Five Laws of Stratospheric Success and teach him how to open himself up to the power of giving.

Joe learns that changing his focus from getting to giving—putting others’ interests first and continually adding value to their lives—ultimately leads to unexpected returns.

Imparted with wit and grace, The Go-Giver is a heartwarming and inspiring tale that brings new relevance to the old proverb “Give and you shall receive.”
results.name: Book Club: The Go Giver by Bob Burg & John David Mann

results.description:
Hello Hikers,

David Fausch has been an active member of the hiking group since inception.   He has been committed, fun, and playful as well as an excellent hiker.   David has taken a position at the International School of Belgium and will be leaving New York City for good as of June 25th.   I will miss Dave's positive spirit and endless ability to laugh and have fun.   I will also miss watching him eating an artery busting, defibrillator mandatory, breakfast sandwich at Grand Central before hikes.   

In a perfect world I would say if you are one of the few who haven't made out with Dave you should join the hike as it may be your last opportunity.   But alas, Dave is now partnered with Chris with whom he will share a home in Brussels.  I am told he will give hikers  who want to visit first dibs on the spare bedroom.  

Dave and I selected the Ossining to Croton Harmon hike since it can accommodate many hikers with no cap on attendance.    Please pester Dave into coming to Uncle Charlies after the hike for a cold good bye beer.  Feel free stop by if you can't make the hike to say good bye to Dave.   Plan 5-6ish. 

Old and new members should feel free to attend.  It's a good opportunity to meet Dave and a bunch of great hikers.  

About the Hike


The hike follows the route of the historic Old Croton Aqueduct from Ossining to Quaker Bridge, continues through parkland in the Village of Croton, and returns via the Croton Harmon Train Station.  Some of the nicest parts of the Aqueduct Trail are on this stretch.  The Croton Dam is spectacular and not to be missed.  

It’s not a long hike, about 7.5 miles and will take 5-6 hours.  It is considered easy to moderate. 

Meet at the Grand Central information booth at 9:30.  We will take the 9:43 to Ossining arriving at 10:30.

Bring plenty of water and a packed lunch.  We will find a nice place to stop along the way.  NO PETS ON THIS HIKE PLEASE.   

Follow the link for more details. 

http://www.nynjtc.org/hike/old-croton-aqueduct-ossining-quaker-bridge
results.name: A Farewell to David Fausch Hike

results.description:
Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text or call Mane at[masked]-6601.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

results.description:
The  first weekend of any month you can get into Liberty Science Center free with a Bank of America card ! !  (as well as many other museums which makes having their card a great bargain if you use it for such).   You  will  still have to pay 10 for  the premium exhibit.  

If you do not have B of A card: prices vary  check out their website:

Please plug Liberty Science Center into your browser.  I have had trouble connecting otherwise to their stated website ! !

There may also be a current Living Social deal, you can check that out too if you do not have a Bank of America card.


The Liberty Science Center currently has an exhibit about the TITANIC, the ill-fated ship that sank on its maiden voyage in April, 1912.  This is a story that continues to fascinate everyone.  The Center has 100 authentic artifacts presented with replicas of cabins and other areas in the ill-fated ship.

We can meet at the center and I will give my cell phone number to those attending.  You must have a clear picture of yourself to sign up and you must give me your contact information so we will not be waiting for someone who decides last minute not to show up and decides not to call (happens ALL the time).   I will email attendees my information a day or two prior to the event.  Therefore, you must not 'block' contact with organizers or other members.  This limits your information received.  You never have to 'answer' anyone you think is a scammer or whatever.

I now have 4 others riding with me:  Bev (neighbor, Ken, Sinikka & Anna).  

Check out www.youtube.com  for many short videos about the Titanic.  I particularly enjoyed 'Titanic treasures found.'  Plug in 'Titanic' in the youtube browser and you will see a lot of great presentations !
results.how_to_find_us: We will be near the entrance ! Inside or outside  3 of us total.  Ken is coming (the leader) with 2 in his car.  Others, look for either group!
results.name: SEE THE TITANIC EXHIBIT AT LIBERTY SCIENCE CENTER ! !

results.description:
Thrive in the Park is a place to meet friends, have fun and get fit.

Our *donation based workouts are designed by fitness experts and are for everyone, at any level of fitness. 

WORKOUT DETAILS:


The work out consists of body weight exercises (ex. pushup, sit ups, squats, lunges, jumps), team competitions, partner exercises, and cardio (jumping jacks, jogging, sprints, jump rope).

We do not count reps, but rather have a "do as many as you can in 1 minute" style of encouragement.

If you have any questions, please send us a message and we'll get back to you within 24 hours.

WHAT TO BRING:


A water bottle, your determination and your *donation*. All donations are invested back into Thrive in the Park

TESTIMONIALS:

Achelle - "#ThriveInThePark is the workout I look forward to all week! Not only do I get an incredible full body workout, but it's a fun and encouraging group to be apart of!"

Maria - "#ThriveInThePark is what I look forward to every week, there is nothing cooler than working out, laughing, and bonding with great people who care for their health. Rain or shine we thrive."

Andie - "#ThriveInThePark I never thought I would enjoy waking up early on a Saturday, but now I look forward to it, fun workouts with friends that keep you motivated to push yourself!"

Dani - "#ThriveInThePark I Love everything about it! Such a positive way to bring community together for some weekend activity. The guys/girls that lead the workout and stretches bring such great energy to the group, we basically laugh the whole time - until the lunges and burpees come along, no one laughs at those."

Devon - "#ThriveInThePark provides a necessary jolt of inspiration and aspiration to anyone looking to improve their life."

Ben - "#ThriveInThePark is all about community and giving back, I couldn't think about a better way to spend my Saturday mornings."

Marco - #ThriveInThePark is great because it connects mind body and soul! We learn new techniques, we motivate each other and meet interesting people from all over the world!"

HISTORY:

Thrive in the Park started in the spring of 2014. We believe in giving back to the community and in creating ripples of kindness, strength and gratitude. It is our hope that you too, will go into the world and create these ripples. 

We can't wait to see you!

LINKS:

http://www.ThriveInThePark.com 

Sponsored by: http://www.soRipe.com

results.description:
The Women of African Descent Film Festival (WADFF) is celebrating its 15th Anniversary in 2016. The media constantly bombards us with negative images of people of African descent. Our positive accomplishments, uplifting experiences, and gifts to humanity get little attention. The Brooklyn Chapter believes it is vitally important that our legacy be maintained, nurtured and preserved and it is our responsibility to shape the public’s perception of who we are as a people. Through the medium of film, filmmakers of African descent document and relay the stories of our past, present, and future. They have become the new historians –“preservers of our legacy.” The Brooklyn Chapter realizes that many societal misconceptions start with how we are portrayed in the media. To counteract the adverse portrayal of African Americans in the movies and media, the Brooklyn Chapter, in 2002, initiated Linkages: Women of African Descent Film Festival. By choosing and screening films that depict the positive linkages that women of African descent have to their families, neighborhoods and communities, the film festival is able to effectively influence peoples’ perceptions through the medium of film.

The festival will take place Saturday, May 7, 2016 at LIU Brooklyn (Corner of Flatbush and DeKalb Avenues), Media Arts Department, Spike Lee Screening Room from 10am-6pm.
results.name: Women of African Descent Film Festival

results.description:
About This Walk

Note: after this walk, attendees will have the option to receive discounted admission to One World Observatory. Also, we'll be right at the site of the America's Cup warmup races, which are happening on the Hudson at 2 pm each day!

Hello! On this walk, with the aid of numerous images, we will first discuss the Downtown West neighborhood before the original WTC was built. Then we'll delve into the design, purpose, and impact of the original WTC. We will briefly review the events of 9/11 and its effects on downtown Manhattan. 

Next, we'll discuss the competitions and proposals to rebuild: which would you have chosen? We will learn about the direct influence that Jane Jacobs' ideas had on the rebuilding plan, and we'll talk about the results so far. Is the plan successful? Is the area more or less welcoming and “user-friendly” than in the past? All opinions are welcome! 

Our walk will take us in or around the Memorial Plaza and pools, the new WTC Transportation Hub and Oculus, the finished Towers 1, 4, and 7, and the unfinished Liberty Park, Performing Arts Center, and Towers 3 and 2. Particular emphasis will be placed on the design and construction of One World Trade Center (Freedom Tower), the tallest building in the Western Hemisphere and the most expensive building on Earth. 

We will discuss what makes today's skyscrapers safer for their occupants than those of the past, and what compromises and costs are necessary to ensure that safety. 

Finally, we will look at the dramatic impact the new World Trade Center is having on the rapid evolution of downtown Manhattan.

Taking Public TransitClosest: E Train to World Trade Center. Or, 1, 2, 3, A, C trains to Chambers Street. Or J, Z, 4, 5 trains to Fulton Street. Or R train to Cortlandt Street
results.name: World Trade Center Walking Tour ! FREE!

The Institute for Architectural Research is offering a session on analytical drawing: an educational workshop designed to develop fundamental drawing skills required to see and think as an architect. Columbus Circle will be our lab as we learn the basic skills to interpret exterior space & building form through profile, proportion, and scale. 

Classes are open to all levels of experience; there are no requirements for sketchbooks or pencil supplies; please be prepared with your own material. 


If you would like to buy supplies, the Institute for Architectural Research offers sketching kit with a sketchbook, pencils, erasers; kits are hand delivered at the beginning of each workshop. 

Students are taught one-on-one by experience architectural sketch artists: Michael Sciarrillo, AIA; Scott Aker, AIA; Corey August and Chloe Rice.


Note: we will be drawing outside; classes will held, rain or shine.

results.description:
Awakening is not something only a few spiritually evolved humans can achieve: it is part of everyone's natural potential. In this daylong retreat, rather than meditating to calm and focus your mind, we will learn to intentionally shift into open-hearted awareness, which is already calm, stable, and able to effortlessly focus. It is possible to discover a deep sense of well-being, creativity and unconditional love that is our true nature. Loch will draw from the ancient wisdom of Sutra Mahamudra and other nondual traditions, as well as current neuroscientific research to point us beyond our ego-centered identity in order to live from an open-hearted awareness. This event serves as a deep introduction to the insights recorded in Loch's book, Shift Into Freedom: The Science and Practice of Open-Hearted Awareness

Pre-Registration online is $70.


REGISTER HERE


Registration at the door is $80.

 
This program is eligible for CEU’s, Continuing Education Credits for Social Workers through Family and Children’s Service of Ithaca, Inc., SW CPE #0293, is recognized by the New York State Education Department’s State Board for Social Work as an approved provider of continuing education to LMSWs and LCSWs in New York State. The period of this licensure is from November 18, 2015 – November 30, 2018. Contact Hours (CEU’s) for NYS Social Workers: 5

There is a $15 payment to Family and Children’s Service of Ithaca, Inc for a certificate.

results.description:
RSVP'S BEGIN THURSDAY, APRIL 7TH AT 1:00PM

Explore Manhattan's Upper West Side!  

This is the first in a series of  four tours to raise awareness about the Broadway Mall Association (BMA), a non-profit organization that has worked to beautify and maintain the malls (essentially a linear park) for the past 30 years.  The malls extend from Lincoln Center to  168th Street.  The cost is $10.00 with all proceeds to the BMA. Read more here: <a>www.broadwaymall.org.</a>

From its humble beginning as the hamlets of Harsenville and the village of Bloomingdale, the Upper West has evolved over the past 100 years as one of NYC’s most desirable neighborhoods and one of the most densely settled places in America.  Join us on this guided walk to learn about the history and development of the West Side from farms and country estates to the iconic apartment houses, brownstones and architectural treasures.

The Upper West Side is home to NYC's largest historic district and some of the world's most magnificent apartment buildings and beautiful brownstone streets. The Ansonia at 73rd and Broadway (pictured above in the early 20th century) perhaps has more interesting and fun stories associated with it than any apartment house in the City!  We'll also talk about the history of Broadway as a major thoroughfare having started out as an American Indian trail and also touch upon the creation of both Central Park and Riverside Park.

This is also the "Celebrity Walk" as the neighborhood has been home to countless famous people -- perhaps some of your favorite actors, authors and musicians from Edgar Allan Poe and Rachmaninoff to John and Yoko, Lauren Bacall, Seinfeld and Lady Gaga.

The walk will end in Riverside Park by the Boat Basin at 79th Street. Feel free to bring a picnic lunch or eat at the Boat Basin Cafe restaurant on the Hudson River.

Best regards,

Hank

2. Cleats are permitted, and Sneakers or Turf Shoes are acceptable as well. We play for an hour with a break in the middle. If no volunteered goal keeper, players will rotate the position. We play with corner kicks and throw-ins. Also, everyone should bring a Blue T-Shirt AND a White T-Shirt.

4. Nearest train stations: Brooklyn Bridge (4, 5 & 6), Canal Street (A, B, C, Q, R, N & 6), Chambers Street (J and Z). Citibike station is available right next to the field on Worth Street.

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text or call Mane at[masked]-6601.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

Speaker, trainer, and certified professional coach, Barbara Phillips, will help participants define, design and experience their dream life.

In this fun and highly interactive workshop, you will learn:

·  What is it that you really want in your life – what makes you come alive?

·  How to design a dream for your life that reflects your unique life “blueprint”

·  A 5-point test to determine if your dream is right for you

·  How to step into your life 3 years from now to see how it feels living a life you truly love

·  Simple thinking strategies that will guard you from fear, doubt and worry

Turn your greatest possibility into your reality!

For over 20 years, Barbara has worked with organizations and individuals helping people grow professionally and personally to effectively manage their careers and accelerate their performance and results to create richer, more fulfilling lives.

Barbara’s career has been in Human Resources and Organization Development at Fortune 100 companies.  She earned her BA in Biology from Williams College, MA in Organizational Psychology from Columbia University and Professional Coach Certification from the Institute of Professional Excellence in Coaching and the International Coach Federation.

As an HR Consultant, trainer/facilitator and Career / Retirement / Life Coach, Barbara has worked with numerous clients inside and outside organizations to support their professional and personal goals.

results.description:
***PLEASE NOTE: our members get a 45% discount off advance ticket purchases! See below!***

Personal Note from David: The NYC Vegetarian Food Festival is one of my favorite events all year. Congratulations to Sarah Gross and Nira Paliwoda for producing these amazing and extremely successful events! The last five Food Fests were incredibly fun, educational, and wonderfully delicious.

----------------------------------------

The 6th Annual NYC Vegetarian Food Festival returns to the Metropolitan Pavilion on Saturday & Sunday, May 7-8, 2016!

With over 120 exhibitors, three stages of entertainment, a giant activity-packed kids area, and two floors of fun, the 6th year of this amazing event is not to be missed!

The 2016 Keynote Speaker is Dr. Michael Greger, physician and New York Times bestselling author of the new book, How Not to Die. He will speak on Saturday, May 7th from 2-3:00PM on the Apple Stage.

The 2016 Festival will feature: samples from vegetarian food companies and restaurants, world-class speakers, cooking demonstrations, cookbook signings, health and wellness vendors, 100% vegan meals for sale, animal rescue and eco information tables, live entertainment throughout the day, and children’s arts & crafts activities.


A roster of eight highly credentialed physicians will grace the stages at this year's festival. Festival co-founder and organizer Sarah Gross said the medical emphasis at this year’s event is due to the rising mountain of evidence that a vegan diet is ideal for one’s health. “We energetic vegans have known this in our bones for quite awhile, but it’s nice to be validated by the medical community,” she said.

The doctors scheduled to speak at the Festival include:

Dr. Aysha Akhtar, double Board-certified neurologist and preventive medicine/public health specialist, author of Animals and Public Health, Fellow of the Oxford Centre for Animal Ethics, Lieutenant Commander in the US Public Health Service Commissioned Corps, and regular blogger for the Huffington Post. She received her training at Eastern Virginia Medical School, Washington Hospital Center, and the University of North Carolina Medical School in Chapel Hill.

Dr. Michelle McMacken, Board-certified internal medicine physician, assistant professor of medicine at NYU School of Medicine, and honors graduate of Yale University and Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons. She has more than ten years of experience practicing primary care, directing a medical weight-loss program, and teaching doctors-in-training at Bellevue Hospital Center in NYC.

Dr. Michael Greger, Cornell- and Tufts-trained general practitioner, founding member and Fellow of the American College of Lifestyle Medicine, and author of the books Bird Flu: A Virus of Our Own Hatching and Carbophobia: The Scary Truth Behind America’s Low Carb Craze. His latest book, How Not to Die, became an instant New York Times Best Seller.

Dr. Robert Ostfeld, associate professor of Clinical Medicine at Albert Einstein College of Medicine, director of the Cardiac Wellness Program at Montefiore Medical Center, and associate director of the Cardiology Fellowship at Montefiore-Einstein. He received his training from the University of Pennsylvania, Yale University School of Medicine, the Harvard School of Public Health, and Harvard Medical School.

Dr. Casey Taft, professor of psychiatry at Boston University School of Medicine, associate editor of the journal Psychological Trauma, board member of The War Writers’ Campaign, consultant to the United Nations on preventing violence and abuse globally, and manager of Vegan Publishers. He sees the prevention of violence towards animals as a natural extension of his work.

Dr. Thomas Campbell, medical director of the T. Colin Campbell Center for Nutrition Studies, co-founder and clinical director of the University of Rochester Program for Nutrition in Medicine, Board-certified family physician, and co-author of The China Study. His training is from SUNY Buffalo School of Medicine, the University of Rochester, and Cornell University.

Dr. Garth Davis, fellow of the American College of Surgeons, fellow of the American Society for Metabolic and Bariatric Surgery, co-star of the docu-reality television series Big Medicine, and author of The Expert’s Guide to Weight Loss Surgery and Proteinaholic. He received his training from the University of Texas in Austin, Baylor College of Medicine, and the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor.

Dr. Steve Neabore serves on the Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine and specializes in the prevention and treatment of acute and chronic diseases. He completed his undergraduate degree at New York University and earned his medical degree from St. George’s University, with a residency in internal medicine at New York Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn.


Elite pro athletes who fuel their feats exclusively on plant-based diets will also be among the presenters. Christine Vardaros, a champion cyclist, will speak on “How Pro Athletes Do It.” She began her cycling career in 1996 as a mountain biker for Team Breezer run by Joe Breeze. In 2000 she became a vegan, but it didn’t slow her down. After transitioning to road biking and cyclo-cross, she went on to represent USA Cycling at three World Cyclo-Cross Championships as well as more than 25 World Cups.
  Another athlete scheduled to speak at the Festival is Omowale Adewale, a professional boxer. His talk is entitled “Champion Vegan Nutrition.” Adewale became a vegetarian when he was 15, before getting involved in competitive sports. He taught himself Jeet Kune Do, a form of martial arts, and was also a national finalist in the 1997 Body Building of America competition. In 2012, he became a Super Middleweight Champion in the Brooklyn Brawl. And a few years later, he decided to cut dairy products from his diet to become fully vegan.
  In addition to showcasing doctors and athletes, the Festival will feature speakers on a variety of topics such as animal advocacy and vegan cooking techniques. Speakers include: Edita Birnkrant, Myq Kaplan, Hannah Krum & Alex Lagory, Craig Cochran, Ivan Stratienco, William Siff, Sid Garzahillman, Gene Baur, Annie & Dan Shannon, Cayla Mackey, Meryl Tihanyi, Dr. Andrew Kirchner and Kristin Lajeunesse.
  A large part of the Festival pavilion will be devoted to vegan vendors, many of whom offer free food samples to attendees. Non-profit organizations will also staff tables with literature about their activities.


This year’s charity partner is Mercy For Animals, which will receive proceeds from the Festival raffle.
  The event is family-friendly, with a special area devoted to children’s arts and crafts activities. There will also be performances by a comedian, an illusionist, and other entertainers.
  The NYC Vegetarian Food Festival was launched in 2011. It is presented by U.S. Veg Corp, an event-planning company which also sponsors Vegan Drinks Brooklyn, various cooking competitions, and Meatless Monday meals at local restaurants.


A complete listing of presenters and vendors can be found at: http://nycvegfoodfest.com.

The NYC Vegetarian Food Festival will take place 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. on both Saturday and Sunday, May 7-8, at the Metropolitan Pavilion (125 West 18th Street, between 6th and 7th Avenues).

Dates: Saturday, May 7th and Sunday, May 8th

Time: 11:00 AM-6:00 PM both days

Location: The Metropolitan Pavilion, 125 West 18th Street (between 6th and 7th Avenues), New York, NY

Tickets Purchased at the Door: $35 for either day (Saturday or Sunday) or $60 for a two-day pass. Entry for those purchasing tickets at the door will begin at 1:00PM (based on availability). (So we recommend purchasing tickets in advance, and at a large discount, using our group discount code. See below.)

Advance Ticket Price: $32.23 for either day (Saturday or Sunday), or $53.02 for a two-day pass. (But our group gets a big discount. See below.)

***** We have arranged a 45% discount for our meetup members on advance purchase tickets. Tickets purchased in advance will be only $17.73 for either day (Saturday or Sunday) when using the Discount Code VEGMEETUP. (No discount is available for two-day tickets.) Type VEGMEETUP into the "Discount Code" space after you have added your ticket to your shopping cart. The form to order tickets is located at: https://chirrpy.com/events/nycvff/ *****

Advance Tickets: https://chirrpy.com/events/nycvff/ (Be sure to enter VEGMEETUP in the Discount Code space after adding your ticket to your shopping cart, for a 45% discount on one-day tickets, for either Saturday or Sunday.)

Food Fest Web Site: http://nycvegfoodfest.com

This is one of my favorite events all year. Congratulations to Sarah Gross and Nira Paliwoda for producing these amazing and extremely successful events! The last five Food Fests were incredibly fun, educational, and wonderfully delicious. For a great time, please RSVP and attend.

David
